repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Administrative Capacity
            Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Administrative Capacity
            Building Project for Burkina Faso were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory; risk to development outcome
            was medium/moderate; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: excessive
            optimism in decentralization and de- concentration
            commitment. Focusing on studies, training and Information
            Technology (IT) equipment in a context of serious budget
            constraint means that some studies recommendations will not
            be implemented. A demand-driven project is not a panacea for
            a good design. Public sector reform requires flexibility,
            which can be resource-consuming in the context of a grant.
            Civil servant training and IT equipment do not necessarily
            lead to civil servant behavioral change. Lack of impact
            evaluation for cross-cutting public sector reforms, such as
            decentralization and de-concentration, hampers impact improvement.

Burkina Faso - Administrative Capacity
            Building Project

14000213.trustfund:
TF051876-PHRD-BURKINA FASO: PUBLIC
            SECTOR REFORM CAPACITY BUILDING PROGRAM

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Administrative Capacity
            Building Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The goal of the Administrative Capacity
            Building Project is to improve the performance of the
            administration and enable it to implement key strategic
            choices of the Government of Burkina Faso (GoBF). This
            restructuring paper seeks for the extension of closing date
            for the project to August 31, 2011. This will be the first
            extension of the project closing date.  The project
            achievements to date include: i) the implementation of HR
            management de-concentration; ii) the increase of civil
            service performance, through implementation of the 1998
            evaluation policy; iii) the restructuring of the ministry of
            economy and finance to improve its internal efficiency; and
            iv) the strengthening of public expenditures management
            de-concentration. The extension is necessary to complete the
            extension of the computerized HR management system to line
            ministries in the capital city and to extend the
            computerized pay system to the regions. With the completion
            of these activities the processing of the administrative and
            financial decisions on staff careers will be done on a
            timely manner and the staff located in the provinces will no
            longer have to leave their work place for administrative
            reasons. This extension will also be used to elaborate the
            decentralization strategy.

display_title.display_title:
Burkina Faso - Administrative
            Capacity Building Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

0.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Projet de Renforcement
            des Capacites de I' Administration : procurement plan

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Administrative Capacity
            Building Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Administrative
            Capacity Building Project for Burkina Faso is to assist the
            recipient in improving the rationality, transparency,
            accountability and performance of its administration, by:
            (i) implementing decentralization and de-concentration of
            responsibilities and services, and (ii) building up
            institutional and legal infrastructure. This paper proposes
            the following changes in the project: (i) revision of the
            project's results monitoring framework by reformulating
            the Project Development Objective (PDO) and streamlining the
            number of Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) used in the
            project; (ii) reduction in the number of project components
            from six to three; and  (iii) re-allocation of grant
            resources across the new components to ensure efficiency in
            the utilization of grant resources and to reflect the
            changing priorities of government.
